tn.text: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. AT: "he considered himself righteous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Then was kindled the anger of Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram; it was kindled against Job
tn.text: This compares Elihu's anger to someone starting a fire. Also, this can be stated in active form. AT: "Then Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, became very angry with Job" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a people-group. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: he justified himself rather than God
tn.text: This means that he considered himself innocent and believed God had been wrong to punish him. AT: "he justified himself and claimed that God had been wrong to punish him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Elihu's anger was also kindled against his three friends
tn.text: This compares Elihu's anger to someone starting a fire. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Elihu also became very angry with his three friends" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. This tells background information about Elihu. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: that there was no answer in the mouths of these three men
tn.text: This means that the men were done speaking to Job. This speaks of the men possibly having an answer as if the answer were an object that would be in their mouths. AT: "that these three men had nothing else to say" or "and these three men had no more answers to give Job" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This compares Elihu's anger to someone starting a fire. This can be stated in active form. AT: "he became very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "you" is plural and refers to Job and his three friends. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: Length of days should speak; a multitude of years should teach wisdom
tn.text: These two lines mean the same thing. Elihu emphasizes that since older people are wiser than younger people, they should be the first to speak of what they know. AT: "He who has lived many years should speak; He would is older should teach wisdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Elihu continues speaking to Job and his friends.

tn.ref: there is a spirit in a man ... the breath of the Almighty
tn.text: Both phrases mean the same thing. Elihu is emphasizing that a man's wisdom comes from God. AT: "there is a spirit in a man, that is, the breath of the Almighty that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Here the spirit is represented by "breath." AT: "the spirit of the Almighty" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Elihu uses this word here to draw the mens' attention to what he says next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The word "you" refers to Job's friends. Their "words" refers to what they would say. AT: "I waited to hear what you would say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: who could respond to his words
tn.text: Here the word "respond" does not just mean to answer, but to answer with a profitable response.
Elihu continues speaking to Job's friends.
"We have discovered what is wise." This means that they believe that they have figured out what is wise.
This speaks of God responding to Job and correcting him as if he were defeating him in battle. AT: "to refute Job" or "to answer Job" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"by saying what you have said"
Elihu continues speaking.
"speechless"

tn.ref: Should I wait because they are not speaking, because they stand there silent and answer no more?
tn.text: Elihu uses a question to emphasize that he will not wait any longer to speak. Elihu answers this question himself in the next verse. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Elihu continues speaking using parallelisms.

tn.ref: I also will answer on my part
tn.text: "I will now take my turn to answer"
Elihu speaks of having a lot to say as being full of words. AT: "I have so much to say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the spirit in me compels me
tn.text: "my spirit forces me to say it" (UDB)

tn.ref: my breast is like fermenting wine that has no vent ... like new wineskins, it is ready to burst
tn.text: While wine is fermenting, gas collects in the container. If the gas is not let out the container will burst. Elihu means that he has so much to say that if he does not speak he feels like he will burst. Also, these two phrases are parallel and have the same meaning. AT: "I feel like my breast is about to burst, like a container of fermenting wine that has no vent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This represents Elihu, specifically his spirit. AT: "my spirit is" or "I am"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Elihu continues speaking using parallelisms for emphasis.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "I may feel better" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here the "lips" represent the mouth. AT: "open my mouth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: neither will I give honorific titles to any man
tn.text: "neither will I praise any man or give him titles of honor"
"God who made me." This is a name referring to God.
This means that he would destroy him. AT: "destroy me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
